#Text=Poverty rises as food prices increase
#Text=Sunday , April 17 , 2011
#Text=Various grains .
#Text=Image : Rainer Zenz .
#Text=The World Bank , an organization that provides loans to developing countries , warned Thursday that rising food prices are driving millions of people deeper into poverty .
#Text=Robert Zoelick , World Bank president , said that food prices have risen 36 % over the last year , pushing 44 million more people into poverty since last June .
#Text=About 1.2 billion people are extremely poor .

#Text=He warned that a further increase of 10 % in the cost of food would move an additional 10 million persons into extreme poverty , and there was no sign of a near term reversal in the inflation of food prices , which affects the developing world disproportionately .
#Text=" We have to put food first and protect the poor and vulnerable , who spend most of their money on food , " said Zoellick .
#Text=“ The general trend lines are ones where we are in a danger zone … because prices have already gone up and [ food ] stocks are relatively low , ” he said .
#Text=The general trend lines are ones where we are in a danger zone .
#Text=— Robert Zoelick , World Bank president
#Text=The cost of the basic foods , such as wheat , maize and soy are all surging .
#Text=Only rice has shown a slight decrease in price .

#Text=The steep rise in the cost of food is being driven by a combination of factors , including bad weather in food exporting areas such as Russia , Ukraine , North America and China , rising energy costs that increase the cost of producing and transporting food , and the incentives for farmers in many countries to produce crops for biofuel s instead of for food .
#Text="

#Text=He hopes to discuss food policies with officials of the G-20 countries to develop a  code of conduct " on export bans and to encourage these countries to do more to increase food production and aid developing countries in managing agricultural problems .

column1: #Text=On Saturday , the World Bank and the IMF issued " Global Monitoring Report 2011 : Improving the Odds of Achieving the MDGs " which said the world was still on track toward reaching a key goal of reducing the number of the world 's people living in extreme poverty and hunger by half , to 883 million , by the target date of 2015 .

column1: #Text=Most of the world 's progress is due to fast growth in India and China , while African countries are behind .
